choices.text: It is known as hybridoma technique.
The mouse cells are the source of immortal cells, whereas the myeloma cells are the source of antibodies.
Aminopterin blocks the de novo pathway for purine synthesis.
Chimeric mAb: It is prepared by the recombination of 34% mouse proteins (variable region) and 66% human proteins (constant region).

questions.text: All of the following statements are true for the technique shown in the image except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This image shows the production of Monoclonal antibodies by the Hybridoma technique.
  • Myeloma cells are the source of immortal cells, while mouse cells are the source of antibodies. (Option B ruled out)
  • A clone of B cells stimulated against a single epitope of antigen is fused with an immortal cell, e.g. myeloma cell (capable of multiplying indefinitely) to produce a hybridoma cell. This hybridoma cell has two unique properties:
    • Produces monoclonal antibodies of the same antigen specificity (due to B cell component)
    • Multiplies indefinitely, producing clones of identical cells (due to the immortal myeloma cell component).

Steps of the hybridoma technique

  • Mouse splenic B cells: The mouse is injected with an antigen containing the desired epitope. After an interval, the mouse splenic B cells are obtained, which are activated against the epitope of the antigen injected.
  • Myeloma cells are used as a source of immortal cells.They are cancerous plasma cells. They closely resemble mouse B cells; hence are compatible for fusion.
  • HAT medium is used here. It contains hypoxanthine, aminopterin and thymidine.
  • Purine synthesis in mammalian cells (e.g. splenic B cells) occurs by either de novo or salvage pathways.
  • Aminopterin blocks the de novo pathway so that the cell has to perform the salvage pathway to synthesise purines for its survival (Option C ruled out).
  • Salvage pathway requires two important enzymes- HGPRT (hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl-transferase) and thymidine kinase. So any cell (e.g. myeloma cell) that lacks HGPRT cannot grow on HAT medium.

Fate of three types of cells on HAT media:

  • Unfused splenic B cells: They can grow, but do not survive long, as they are not immortal
  • Unfused myeloma cells: They cannot grow as they lack the HGPRT enzyme to perform the salvage pathway of purine synthesis
  • Hybridoma cells: They can grow and survive long time.

Types of Monoclonal Antibodies

  • Mouse mAb: It contains 100% mouse-derived proteins.
  • Chimeric mAb: It is prepared by recombination of 34% mouse proteins (variable region) and 66% human proteins (constant region) (Option D ruled out).
  • Humanised mAb: Here, only the antigen-binding site (i.e. CDR-complementarity-determining region) is mouse-derived (10%) and the remaining part of the mAb is human-derived.
  • Human mAb: It contains 100% human-derived amino acids. It is the best accepted mAb in humans.

questions.text: The test shown in the picture works based on the principle of:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Rapid antigen tests for COVID-19 typically utilise the lateral flow assay (LFA) method.

Lateral Flow Assay (LFA)

  • In LFA, a sample (such as nasal swab fluid) is placed on one end of a test strip that is coated with specific antibodies for the COVID-19 antigens (usually spike proteins).
  • The sample moves across the test strip by capillary action. If the target antigen (in this case, the SARS-CoV-2 antigen) is present, it binds to the antibodies and forms a visible line (such as a coloured band) at a specific spot on the test strip, indicating a positive result.

Explanation of other options:

Flow through assay (Option B): Similar to LFA, but the fluid passes through the entire membrane and is captured at a specific site. It is not commonly used for COVID-19 antigen tests.

Chemiluminescence Linked Immunoassay (CLIA) (Option C): Involves a chemiluminescent reaction to detect the presence of an antigen or antibody. While CLIA is used in some COVID-19 testing platforms, it is not the principle behind most rapid antigen tests.

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) (Option D): This test involves a more complex and time-consuming process that detects either antigens or antibodies. It is typically used for research or laboratory-based diagnostics, not rapid tests..

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl was playing at the beach when she cut her foot on a sharp object. Three days later, she was brought to the emergency room because of pain and swelling at the site of the wound and drainage of pus from it. The most likely cause of the infection is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical History of salt water, trauma and wound infection suggests a causative organism as Vibrio vulnificus.

  • Vibrio vulnificus belongs to a class of vibrios called Halophilic vibrios, which can withstand up to 6% salinity.
  • It can cause two distinct syndromes:
    • Primary sepsis: Usually occurs in patients with underlying liver disease and iron overload, or rarely in renal insufficiency and immunosuppression
    • Primary wound infection: It is characterised by painful erythematous swelling or cellulitis or even vesicular, bullous or necrotic lesions, generally affecting people without underlying disease.

Explanation of other options:

Escherichia coli (Option B): E. coli can cause wound infections, but it is typically associated with faecal contamination and is more common in intestinal infections. It is not as likely in a saltwater wound scenario.

Aeromonas hydrophila (Option C): Aeromonas hydrophila is a gram-negative bacillus commonly found in freshwater environments, such as rivers and streams. It is a known pathogen that causes wound infections following trauma from contaminated water.

Proteus mirabilis (Option D): Proteus species can cause infections, particularly in urinary tract infections or wounds, but it is less commonly associated with saltwater-associated injuries

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents with complaints of abdominal pain and 10 episodes of passing foul-smelling dark stool mixed with blood and mucus. There is no history of fever and tenesmus. There is localised tenderness in the right iliac fossa on examination. What is the infective form of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Given history is suggestive of Amoebic dysentery caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The infective form of which is a Mature quadrinucleate cyst.

  • Entamoeba histolytica has two main forms in its life cycle:
    • Cyst:
      • Immature cyst (Precyst)
      • Mature quadrinucleate cyst: Infective stage
    • Trophozoite
  • The infective form of Entamoeba histolytica is the mature cyst, which is ingested through contaminated food or water.
  • Once ingested, the cyst undergoes excystation in the small intestine, releasing trophozoites, which then cause tissue damage and inflammation in the colon, leading to symptoms like bloody diarrhoea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.

Explanation of other options:

Metacyclic trophozoite (Option B): Metacyclic trophozoites are the infective form of Trypanosoma.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room with symptoms of meningoencephalitis, including fever, headache, nausea, vomiting, and altered mental status. A wet mount examination of his cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) reveals the presence of motile unicellular organisms. Based on the findings, which of the following organisms is most likely to be the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of motile unicellular organisms in the CSF is a classic sign of Naegleria fowleri infection.

  • Naegleria fowleri is a free-living amoeba that can cause primary amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM).
  • It is typically acquired through exposure to warm, contaminated freshwater, where the amoeba enters the body through the nasal passages.

Explanation of other options:

Acanthamoeba castellani (Option B): Acanthamoeba castellani is another free-living amoeba that can cause granulomatous amebic encephalitis (GAE). However, it is typically seen in immunocompromised individuals and has a slower progression than Naegleria fowleri. Although it can cause encephalitis, the presentation is generally more insidious, and it is less likely to present with the rapid onset of symptoms seen in this case.

Entamoeba histolytica (Option C): Entamoeba histolytica causes amoebic dysentery and sometimes liver abscesses. It is a cause of intestinal infection.

Trypanosoma cruzi (Option D): Trypanosoma cruzi causes Chagas disease, which primarily affects the heart and gastrointestinal system. While Trypanosoma cruzi can lead to neurological complications in chronic infection (such as meningoencephalitis in rare cases), it is not motile in the CSF like the organisms described in the scenario.

Key takeaway:

questions.text: A patient presents with painful subcutaneous nodules on the face and oedema of the eyelid, as shown in the photo. Which of the following acts as a vector in the transmission of this disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with painful subcutaneous noduleson the face and oedema of the eyelid is highly suggestive of Chagas disease (also known as American trypanosomiasis).
  • This disease is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, a protozoan parasite, and can present with oedema and subcutaneous nodules (particularly around the eyes), a characteristic feature known as Romana's sign.
  • The vector for Chagas diseaseis the Reduviid bug, also called the kissing bug, which transmits the Trypanosoma cruzi parasite through its faeces.
  • The patient often gets infected when the bug's faeces are deposited near the bite site, and scratching or rubbing the area can introduce the parasite into the body.

Explanation of other options:

Tsetse fly (Option A): The Tsetse fly transmits Trypanosoma brucei, causing African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness).

Simulium fly (Option C): The Simulium fly transmits Onchocerca volvulus, causing onchocerciasis (river blindness), which presents with symptoms like skin itching and vision problems.

Sand fly (Option D): The sand fly is the vector for Leishmania species, which cause leishmaniasis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with vaginal itching, discharge, and painful urination. She describes the discharge as frothy, yellow-green, and having a strong odour. On pelvic examination, the vaginal mucosa is erythematous, and a strawberry cervix is observed. A wet mount of the discharge reveals motile organisms. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan parasite that causes trichomoniasis, which presents with frothy, yellow-green discharge with a strong odour, vaginal itching, and pain during urination.
  • The finding of motile organisms on a wet mount is characteristic of Trichomonas vaginalis, and the associated strawberry cervix (erythematous appearance of the cervix with small punctate haemorrhages) is a classic clinical sign.

Explanation of other options:

Gardnerella vaginalis (Option A): These are causative agents of bacterial vaginosis, typically presenting with a thin, greyish vaginal discharge that has a characteristic fishy odour. Patients usually remain asymptomatic.

Mycoplasma hominis (Option C): Can cause PID and Bacterial vaginosis associated with Gardnerella vaginalis.

Candida albicans (Option D): Candidal vaginitis presents with vaginal itching associated with thick curdy vaginal discharge.

questions.text: An anxious mother brought her 6-year-old daughter in with complaints of passing loose, bulky stools for the past 16 days associated with abdominal pain. On stool examination, the following result was obtained on iodine mount. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above images show a tetra-nucleated oval cyst with an axostyle, which is characteristic of Giardia lamblia.
  • Giardia lamblia is a protozoan parasite that causes giardiasis, which is often characterised by chronic watery diarrhoea, abdominal pain, bloating, and steatorrhea (fatty, bulky stools).
  • The Infective form of Giardia lamblia is the Binucleate cyst
  • The bulky stools described in the clinical scenario are typical of giardiasis, and it commonly causes chronic diarrhoea in children. The stools may appear pale and fatty due to malabsorption.

Life cycle of Giardia:


Explanation of other options:

E. histolytica (Option A): Entamoeba histolytica is the causative agent of amoebiasis, which typically causes bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and dysentery. While it can lead to chronic diarrhoea, it more commonly presents with invasive disease (e.g., amoebic liver abscesses).

Cryptosporidium (Option C): These are protozoan parasite that causes cryptosporidiosis, typically leading to watery diarrhoea. It can cause chronic diarrhoea, especially in immunocompromised individuals.

E. coli (Option D): Certain strains of E.coli, like enterotoxigenic E. coli, can cause diarrhoea. They are more often linked to watery diarrhoea, abdominal cramping, and sometimes fever.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Parasites and egg morphology

choices.text: Each oocyst has 2 sporocysts, with each having 2 sporozoites
Oocyst has 2 sporocysts,s each having four sporozoites

questions.text: A 52-year-old male got a kidney transplant 14 weeks ago. He has been complaining of diarrhoea for 5 weeks. On stool microscopy, autofluorescence is observed. The size of the oocyst is 10 micrometres. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Findings of an Oocyst of size 10 micrometres with autofluorescence are suggestive of Cyclospora infection.
  • Patient has a history of kidney transplantation, so he will be on immunosuppressants. An immunocompromised person presenting with chronic diarrhoea (>4 weeks) suggests a diagnosis of Coccidians.
  • Cyclospora oocyst will have 2 sporocysts, with each having 2 sporozoites. (Option A ruled out)
  • Occasionally of cyclospora stains is variable and acid-fast. (Option D ruled)

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive male presents with fever, headache, confusion, and focal neurological deficits. His CD4 count is 80/μL, and he has not been adherent to antiretroviral therapy. A CT scan of the brain reveals multiple ring-enhancing lesions. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a mildly elevated white blood cell count with predominantly lymphocytes and mildly elevated protein. What is the gold standard investigation for the organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An immunocompromised state in HIV (CD4 < 200) with neurological deficits and ring-enhancing lesion + lymphocytosis in CSF suggests toxoplasmosis.

Sabin-Feldman Dye test:

  • This is the gold standard antibody detection method for Toxoplasma gondii, usually done in the reference laboratories.
  • Other serological tests are evaluated taking this test as a standard.
  • It is a complement-mediated neutralisation test that requires live tachyzoites.

Differential diagnosis of ring-enhancing lesions on neuroimaging:

  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Teania solium
  • TB
  • Metastasis

Explanation of other options:

Taenia Solium - CT scan (Option B): Taenia Solium is the causative organism of neurocysticercosis, not toxoplasmosis. While it can also present with ring-enhancing lesions, the diagnosis would be confirmed with serological tests and inspection of cysts on imaging, not by CT alone. This scenario is more consistent with toxoplasmosis.

Metastasis - CT scan (Option C): Brain metastasis can cause ring-enhancing lesions, but it is not the most likely diagnosis in this HIV-positive patient with low CD4. Brain metastasis would typically show a single lesion or multiple lesions at different stages. Metastatic lesions are more likely to occur in patients with a known history of cancer.

Tuberculosis - CBNAAT (Option D): Tuberculosis (TB) can cause meningeal tuberculosis or brain TB, but it is not the most likely cause of ring-enhancing lesions in this patient because CSF analysis would show very high protein levels and the presence of cob web coagulum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female from a village in Bihar came to the hospital with a history of fever on and off for the past year and recently developed unilateral swelling of the left lower limb. Her blood sample was sent for peripheral blood smear examination, which revealed microfilariae, 240 μm in length, with tail tips pointed free of nuclei. What is the etiological diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario and findings are suggestive of Elephantiasis by W.bancrofti.

Lymphatic Filariasis:

Lymphatic filariasis passes through four stages.

  • Endemic normal
  • Asymptomatic Microfilaremia
  • Acute Filariasis (acute adenolymphangitis)
  • Chronic Filariasis

The manifestations in descending order of occurrence are

  • Hydrocele (most common manifestation): Accumulation of clear straw colored fluid in the cavity of the tunica vaginalis of the testes.
  • Elephantiasis (swelling of the lower limb or, less commonly, arm, vulva or breast)
  • Lymphedema is initially a pitting type (stage-1), which becomes non-pitting and irreversible on limb elevation (stage-2), followed by brawny lymphedema with thickening of the skin (grade-3), finally leading to fibrosis and fissuring (grade-4)
  • Chronic funiculitis and epididymitis.
  • Chyluria: Excretion of chyle, a milky white fluid in urine, may occur rarely. This is due to rupture of lymph vessels into the urinary system.

questions.text: A child, while playing, was searching for his ball and mistakenly hit a beehive. He had several bee stings and a few minutes later developed shock, respiratory failure and vascular collapse. The underlying cause for this reaction in the patient is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • IgE-mediated hypersensitivity/Type 1 hypersensitivity/Immediate hypersensitivity is the most common cause of anaphylaxis in a bee sting.
  • In this case, the person must be pre-sensitised, i.e, have a prior history of Bee sting.
  • IgE antibodies bind to mast cells and basophils at first exposure. When the person is re-exposed to the allergen, these antibodies trigger the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators.
  • The release of these mediators causes vasodilation, bronchoconstriction, swelling, and increased vascular permeability, leading to shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse, which are the symptoms described in the scenario.

Type 1 hypersensitivity examples: (mnemonic; STOP ABCD)

  • S - Schultz Dale phenomenon
  • T - Theobald Smith phenomenon
  • O - food allergy
  • P - PK reaction, parasitic diseases like Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia (TPE), Loeffler's pneumonia (Ascaris)
  • A - Anaphylaxis, allergies, atopy
  • B - Bronchial asthma
  • C - Casoni's test
  • D - Drugs

questions.text: An 80-year-old male had complaints of drooping of eyelids, double vision and progressive muscular weakness towards the end of the day. His condition improved after giving him edrophonium. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is responsible for the disease in Ayushee's grandfather?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical history is characteristic of myasthenia gravis, an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder, an example of Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction.
  • This condition is caused by autoantibodiesthat block the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, impairing communication between the nerve and muscle, which results in muscle weakness.

Type 2 HSR examples: (mnemonic - MY BLOOD GROUP IS RH POSITIVE)

  • Myasthenia Gravis
  • Blood Transfusion Reaction
  • Goodpasture Syndrome (* all glomerulonephritis are type 3 HSR except Goodpasture Syndrome, Graves' Disease)
  • Immune Hemolytic Anemia, Immune thrombocytopenic
  • Rh Incompatibility, Rheumatic heart disease
  • Pemphigus (Bullous), Pernicious Anaemia

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby was brought in with a severe diaper rash. The parents gave a history of recurrent infections since birth. This time, the baby was brought to the hospital having a rash with centripetal distribution and of different stages. The biopsy of the thymus showed remnants of Hassall's corpuscles. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).
  • The biopsy of the thymus showing remnants of Hassall's corpuscles indicates it is due to adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency. (Options A, B, D ruled out)
  • SCID is a defect in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses.
  • Affected infants present with prominent thrush (oral candidiasis), extensive diaper rash, and failure to thrive.
  • Some patients develop a morbilliform rash shortly after birth because maternal T cells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including:

  • Candida albicans
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci
  • Pseudomonas
  • Cytomegalovirus
  • Varicella

There are 2 types of SCID based on inheritance:

X-linked SCID:

  • Most common form: more common in boys than in girls.
  • The genetic defect is the mutation in the common y-chain (yc) subunit of cytokine receptors.
  • T cell numbers are greatly reduced.
  • The thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated epithelial cells resembling fetal thymus.
  • X-linked SCID is the first human disease in which gene therapy has been successful.

Autosomal recessive:

  • To deficiency of the enzyme adenosine deaminase (ADA) leads to the accumulation of deoxyadenosine and its derivatives (e.g., deoxy-ATP). They are toxic to rapidly dividing immature lymphocytes, especially those of the T-cell lineage.
  • There may be a greater reduction in the number of T lymphocytes.
  • The thymus is small and devoid of lymphoid cells: remnants of Hassall's corpuscles can be found.

Explanation of other options:

Transient Hypogammaglobulinemia of Infancy (Option A):

  • A temporary delay in the normal maturation of immunoglobulin production in infants, leading to low IgG levels (and sometimes IgA/IgM) between 3-6 months of age.
  • Spontaneous resolution by 2-4 years.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Recurrent sinopulmonary infections (otitis media, bronchitis).
    • Mild/moderate infections.
    • No opportunistic infections (intact T-cell function).

Common variable immunodeficiency (Option B):

  • A primary immunodeficiency characterised by:
    • Hypogammaglobulinemia (low IgG, IgA, and/or IgM).
    • Poor antibody response to vaccines/infections.
    • Recurrent bacterial infections, autoimmunity, and lymphoproliferative complications.
  • Clinical Manifestations
    • Recurrent sinopulmonary infections (pneumonia, sinusitis, otitis).
    • Chronic diarrhoea (Giardia, Campylobacter).
    • Enteroviral meningoencephalitis (rare but severe).
    • Autoimmunity (ITP, AIHA, rheumatoid-like arthritis).
    • Granulomatous disease (sarcoid-like lesions in lungs/spleen).
    • Lymphoproliferation (splenomegaly, nodular lymphoid hyperplasia).
    • Increased cancer risk (lymphoma, gastric cancer).

DiGeorge syndrome (Option D):

  • A chromosomal disorder caused by a microdeletion at 22q11.2, leading to abnormal development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches.
  • Clinical Manifestations:
    • Cardiac:- TOF, VSD, Truncus Arteriosus, IAA Type B
    • Abnormal facies:- Hypertelorism, low-set ears, micrognathia, short philtrum, cleft palate
    • Thymic hypoplasia:- T-cell deficiency
    • Hypocaclcemia

Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30969584/

choices.text: Revascularisation (day 3-7) → cellular infiltration (day 7-8) → decreased vascularisation (day 7-10) → necrosis (day 10-12) → rejection (by day 12-14)
Incomplete revascularisation (day 1-2) → cellular infiltration (day 3-4) → thrombosis and necrosis (day 5-6) → rejection (by day 6)
Decreased vascularisation (day 3-7) → Revascularisation (day 7-10) → necrosis (day 10-12) → rejection (by day 12-14)

questions.text: Which is a typical example of second-set rejection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Autograft Acceptance

  • When a skin graft is transplanted to the same individual at a different site, revascularisation takes place by day 3-7, followed by healing (within day 7-10) and then resolution and acceptance of the graft (by day 12-14).

First-set Rejection

  • When an allograft is placed for the first time from a donor to a recipient, the type of primary graft rejection that develops is known as first-set rejection.
  • The skin first becomes revascularized between days 3 and 7; as the reaction develops, the vascularized transplant becomes infiltrated with lymphocytes, monocytes, neutrophils, and other inflammatory cells.
  • There is decreased vascularisation of the transplanted tissue by 7-10 days, visible necrosis by 10 days, and complete rejection by 12-14 days.

Second-set Rejection:

  • If, in a recipient who has rejected a graft by the first set response, another graft from the same donor is transplanted, it will be rejected in an accelerated fashion.
  • Though vascularisation starts, but is soon interrupted by the inflammatory response. Necrosis sets in early, and the graft sloughs off by the sixth day.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presented with complaints of pain in the right hypochondrium. Ultrasonography revealed a single space-occupying cystic lesion in the right lobe of the liver. The cyst was removed surgically and subjected to histopathological examination, which revealed three-layered cyst walls with attached brood capsules. Identify the disease and the causative agent.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hydatid cyst disease caused by E.granulosus.

  • Hydatid cyst disease is caused by the tapeworm Echinococcus granulosus.
  • This parasitic infection often involves the liver, causing a cystic lesion with three-layered cyst walls and brood capsules (which contain smaller daughter cysts).
  • The outermost layer is fibrous, the middle layer is laminated, and the inner layer is germinal, where the brood capsules form.
  • Histopathological finding: Brood capsules attached to the cyst wall are a hallmark of hydatid cysts.

Transmission

  • The infection is typically transmitted through contact with infected dogs or by ingesting eggs from contaminated food or water.

Definitive Hosts

  • Canines (dogs, foxes, wolves) → Harbour adult tapeworms in intestines.

Intermediate Hosts

  • Herbivores (sheep, cattle) → Develop hydatid cysts (liver, lungs).

Accidental Hosts

  • Humans

Symptoms

  • Right hypochondrium pain is common, and the cyst can become large enough to cause discomfort or pressure on adjacent organs.

Explanation of other options:

Amoebic liver abscess; E.histolytica (Option A): Amoebic liver abscess caused by Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite. The abscess typically presents as a single cyst with high fever, right upper quadrant pain, and elevated liver enzymes. However, the cyst has a single-layered wall.

Fascioliasis; Fasciola hepatica (Option C): Fascioliasis is a parasitic infection caused by the liver fluke Fasciola hepatica. Typically causes inflammation in the liver, leading to symptoms like right upper quadrant pain, fever, and jaundice.

Pyogenic liver abscess; Klebsiella pneumoniae (Option D): Pyogenic abscesses are usually single, unilocular, and filled with pus. The walls are typically thickened. Similar to amoebic abscesses, it can present with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and elevated white blood cell count. Ultrasonography would show a hypoechoic lesion, but without the cystic features of hydatid disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the clinic with painful, fluid-filled blisters on their lips and surrounding skin, as shown in the image below. They report experiencing recurrent outbreaks of similar lesions, especially during times of stress. Identify the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows Herpes Labialis caused by HSV-1.

Explanation of other options:

HSV 4 (Option C): Herpes simplex virus 4, also known as Epstein-Barr virus, primarily causes infectious mononucleosis; does not produce recurrent vesicular oral lesions.

HSV 8 (Option D): Herpes simplex virus 8, or Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus, is associated with Kaposi's Sarcoma and some other malignancies, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS. Presents as purple, red, or brown patches on the skin or mucous membranes.

choices.text: Are readily available and easily produced

questions.text: A hospital epidemiologist is investigating a potential bioterrorism event involving a suspected release of Hantavirus. The outbreak is characterised by several cases presenting with severe respiratory symptoms and a history of rodent exposure in the affected area. Which of the following statements is true regarding Hantavirus as a bioterrorism agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hantavirus as a bioweapon for terrorism is readily available and easily produced.

Bioterrorism is a form where there is deliberate release of biological agents (bacteria, viruses, fungi or their toxins) to cause mass illness or death of people, animals, or plants.

Classification of Bioweapons:

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and single dose of toxoid

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented to your clinic with a knife injury 7 hours before. His history is significant for a complete immunisation before 7 years. According to the recommendation for the prevention of tetanus after injury, which of the following injections would you give to him?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

As per the Tetanus immunisation criteria, relative to immunisation status, a single dose of Tetanus toxoid is administered.

Clean wound: brought within 6 hours with a sterile cut

Unclean wound: brought > 6 hours with sterile cut/unsterile cuts or open or contaminated wounds.

choices.text: Wash wound thoroughly + RIG + ARV + TT
Wash wound + penicillin + ARV + RIG + TT
As cats don't carry rabies, no need of treatment

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy, while playing with his pet cat, got accidentally bitten by it. The wound picture is shown below. What should be the next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This image shows an animal bite of category 3 and should be advised wound wash, anti-rabies vaccine and RIG.

Animal bite wounds (especially cat bites) are prone to infection by Pasteurella multocida, a gram-negative coccobacillus. Hence, prophylactic penicillin (or amoxicillin-clavulanate) is recommended to prevent cat bite abscess or secondary bacterial infection.

questions.text: A patient who underwent splenectomy 2 years ago presents with fever with chills, and a productive cough. Sputum culture on blood agar shows the following. Chest X-ray shows lobar pneumonia. Identify the causative organism:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario is of bacterial pneumonia in a splenectomised patient, along with the photo of Satellitism on blood agar, leading to the diagnosis of H. influenza infection.
  • Pneumonia can occur as a part of an overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI). This is a fatal post-splenectomy complication occurring due to infections with encapsulated organisms such as S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and N. meningitidis
  • It can be prevented by vaccinating against these organisms within 2 weeks of undergoing splenectomy.
  • Satellitismis seen when S. aureus is streaked across a plate of blood agar on which H. influenzae has been inoculated. After overnight incubation, the colonies of H. influenzae will be large and well developed alongside the streak of Staphylococcus and smaller when they are farther away from the streak. This is due to the release of factor V by lysis of RBCs mediated by S. aureus. Factor V is required for the growth of H. influenzae.

Explanation of other options:

Neisseria meningitidis (Option A): This organism is most commonly associated with meningitis and meningococcemia, not typically with pneumonia, though it can occasionally cause pneumonia.

Streptococcus pneumoniae (option C): While Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of pneumonia in splenectomy patients, Haemophilus influenzae is still a significant cause, especially in cases where lobar pneumonia is present. Given the context of this particular patient's clinical scenario and sputum culture results, Haemophilus influenzae remains the most probable cause.

Klebsiella granulomatosis (option D): It causes granulomatous lesions and genital ulcers (as in donovanosis), not typically pneumonia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with fever and joint pain along with a characteristic erythema migrans rash on his left leg. He reports a recent trip to a wooded area where he was exposed to ticks. Which of the following is the primary vector responsible for transmitting this disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

From the characteristic rash, we can diagnose it as Lyme disease, transmitted by the Ixodes tick.

  • Lyme diseaseis caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, a spirochete bacterium, and is transmitted to humans primarily by the bite of an Ixodes tick (also known as the hard / deer tick).
  • Ixodes ticksare commonly found in wooded and grassy areas and are known for transmitting Borrelia burgdorferi through their bites.
  • Clinical Features of Lyme Disease:
    • Erythema migrans:The classic bull's-eye rash that appears around the site of the tick bite.
    • Fever, fatigue, and muscle and joint pains.
    • Arthritiscan occur in later stages, particularly in large joints like the knee.

Explanation of other options:

Soft tick (Option A): Soft ticks (genus Ornithodoros) are primarily responsible for transmitting relapsing fever caused by Borrelia species, but not Lyme disease.

Trombiculid mite (Option C): Trombiculid mites, also known as chiggers, are not involved in transmitting Lyme disease. They cause pruritic dermatitis, but they do not carry the Borrelia burgdorferi bacteria.

Louse (Option D): Lice are vectors for epidemic typhus and trench fever but not for Lyme disease.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with hypotonia, poor feeding, and respiratory distress. On examination, the baby has weak reflexes and decreased muscle tone. There is also an absence of deep tendon reflexes and poor head control. The baby was born to a mother who had no prenatal care and is not vaccinated. They gave a history of feeding honey in the first few days. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Floppy Baby Syndrome is a term used to describe hypotonia in an infant or young child, with weakness, poor feeding, and respiratory difficulty, most probably caused by Botulism.
  • Botulism caused by Clostridium botulinumis the most common cause of floppy baby syndrome. Infants may ingest botulinum spores from contaminated honey or soil, which can lead to the production of botulinum toxin.
  • Toxin inhibits snare proteins, which leads to non-release of neurotransmitters at the neuromuscular junction(pre-synaptic).

Explanation of other options:

Spinal Muscular Atrophy (Option B): This is a genetic disorder that causes progressive muscle weakness, but it typically does not present acutely with hypotonia and respiratory distress as seen in botulism.

Myasthenia Gravis (Option C): This autoimmune disorder causes muscle weakness due to acetylcholine receptor antibodies, but it is rare in infants and generally does not cause floppy baby syndrome in the first few months of life.

Mitochondrial Myopathy (Option D): Mitochondrial myopathies may cause weakness and other symptoms, but the characteristic ragged red fibres are more often found in adults, and the presentation typically includes muscle weakness later in childhood, not acute hypotonia in a newborn.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man working in a leather tannery presents with fever, malaise, and a painful ulcer on his forearm. The lesion started as a small papule but rapidly progressed to an eschar surrounded by oedema. The patient denies any known insect bites or trauma but reports that he frequently handles animal hides. Laboratory tests reveal gram-positive, spore-forming bacilli. Which of the following is used to make a vaccine against it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Clinical history and findings of Gram-positive spore-forming bacilli suggest Bacillus anthracis infection, causing Anthrax.

The vaccine against anthrax is made using the protective antigen(PA) component of the anthrax toxin. The anthrax toxin consists of three components:

  • Lethal factor (LF)
  • Oedema factor (EF)
  • Protective antigen (PA)
  • Protective antigen (PA)is the key component used in the anthrax vaccine because it facilitates the entry of the lethal factor and oedema factor into host cells.
  • The vaccine contains the protective antigen in a non-toxic form, which stimulates the immune system to produce antibodies against the protective antigen, thereby preventing the effects of the toxin.

Explanation of other options:

Lethal factor (Option A): Lethal factor is a toxic component of the anthrax toxin that causes cell death, but it is not used in the vaccine.

Oedema factor (Option C): Oedema factor causes fluid accumulation (oedema) in tissues, but it is not used in the anthrax vaccine.

Whole toxin (Option D): The whole toxin is not used in the vaccine because it would be too dangerous. The vaccine only uses the protective antigen component to stimulate the immune system safely.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with severe pain, swelling, and gas bubbles under the skin following a traumatic injury to his leg. The injury occurred 2 days ago when he stepped on a rusty nail while working at a construction site. On examination, the affected area is swollen, discoloured, and emits a foul odour. There is crepitus on palpation, and the patient is febrile. Nagler's test is performed, and the result of it is shown in the image. What is the toxin responsible for the reaction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows a positive Nagler's test. The clinical history with the finding of Nagler's test positive suggests Gas gangrene, caused by Clostridium perfringens, for which Nagler's test is used to detect the presence of Alpha toxin activity.

  • Alpha toxinis a phospholipase that breaks down cell membranes, leading to tissue necrosis, inflammation, and the production of gas (which causes crepitus).
  • This is the key toxin responsible for the clinical features of gas gangrene..

Explanation of other options:

Epsilon toxin (Option A): Epsilon toxin is a potent neurotoxin that can cause damage to the blood-brain barrier and affect vascular permeability. It disrupts the integrity of the blood-brain barrier, leading to oedema in the brain and neurological damage.

Iota toxin (Option B): Iota toxin is responsible for necrotising enteritis.

Beta toxin (Option C): Beta toxin is an anenterotoxin produced by C. perfringens, which causes necrotising enteritis, also known as pig-bel.
